[[File:Antipat4.png|thumb|right|150px|Library warrant canary relying on active removal designed by [[Jessamyn West (librarian)|Jessamyn West]]]]
A '''warrant canary''' is a method by which a [[communications service provider]] aims to inform its users that the provider has been served with a secret government [[subpoena]] despite legal prohibitions on revealing the existence of the subpoena. The warrant canary typically informs users that there has ''not'' been a secret subpoena as of a particular date. If the canary is not updated for the time period specified by the host or if the warning is removed, users are to assume that the host has been served with such a subpoena. The intention is to allow the provider to warn users of the existence of a subpoena passively, without disclosing to others that the government has sought or obtained access to information or records under a secret subpoena.
Secret subpoenas, such as those covered under 18 U.S.C. [[Patriot Act, Title V#National security authorities|§2709(c)]] of the [[USA Patriot Act]], provide criminal penalties for disclosing the existence of the warrant to any third party, including the service provider's users.<ref>{{Citation |pages=78–79 |work= [[Harvard Journal of Law and Public Policy]] |publication-date=2005 |volume=29 |issue=73 |title=Safety and freedom: Common concerns for conservatives, libertarians, and civil libertarians |author=Nadine Strossen|url=http://www.law.harvard.edu/students/orgs/jlpp/Vol29_No1_Strossen.pdf |accessdate= January 3, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |author=Eunice Moscoso |publication-date=August 17, 2003 |title= Subpoenas Fly In Hunt For Hidden Terrorists|work= [[Palm Beach Post]] |page=1A}}</ref>
United States secret subpoenas or [[national security letters]] originated in the [[Electronic Communications Privacy Act|1986 Electronic Communications Privacy Act]] to be used only against those suspected of being agents of a foreign power.<ref name="appeal">{{Citation |author=Shaun Waterman |publication-date=September 30, 2004 |title=Ashcroft: U.S. will appeal terror-law ruling |work= [[United Press International]] |page= |url= http://www.upi.com/Business_News/Security-Industry/2004/09/30/Ashcroft-US-will-appeal-terror-law-ruling/UPI-66781096585901/|accessdate=January 3, 2014}}</ref> This was revised in 2001 under the [[Patriot Act]] so that secret subpoenas can be used against anyone who may have information deemed relevant to [[Counter-intelligence and counter-terrorism organizations|counter-intelligence]] or terrorism investigations.<ref name="appeal" /> The idea of using negative pronouncements to thwart the nondisclosure requirements of [[court order]]s and served secret warrants was first proposed by Steven Schear on the [[cypherpunk]]s [[Electronic mailing lists|mailing list]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/cypherpunks-lne-archive/message/5869 |title=Re: ISP Utility To Cypherpunks? Yahoo! Groups |publisher=Tech.groups.yahoo.com |date=October 31, 2002 |accessdate=2013-06-13}}</ref> mainly to uncover targeted individuals at [[ISP]]s. It was also suggested for and used by public libraries in 2002 in response to the [[USA Patriot Act]], which would force librarians to disclose the circulation history of any of their patrons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.librarian.net/technicality.html |last=West |first=Jessamyn |title=Five Technically Legal Signs for Your Library |publisher=Librarian.net : avoiding the PATRIOT Act since 2001 |year=2002 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021218044219/http://www.librarian.net/technicality.html |archivedate=December 18, 2002 |accessdate=2013-11-14 |deadurl=unfit }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/sep/09/nsa-sabotage-dead-mans-switch |accessdate=2013-11-14 |title=How to foil NSA sabotage: use a dead man's switch - Technology | publisher=The Guardian (UK) |date=September 9, 2013 |first=Cory |last=Doctorow }}</ref>
== Usage ==
The first commercial use of a warrant canary was by the US [[cloud storage]] provider rsync.net, which began publishing its canary in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/reddit.com/comments/6ecu/an_isp_that_protects_your_data_from_the_nsa/|title=An ISP that protects your data from the NSA|publisher=Reddit - May 26, 2006|accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref> In addition to a [[digital signature]], it provides a recent news headline as proof that the warrant canary was recently posted<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsync.net/resources/notices/canary.txt |title=rsync.net Warrant Canary |publisher=rsync.net |accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref> as well as mirroring the posting internationally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.kozubik.com/john_kozubik/2010/08/the-warrant-canary-in-2010-and-beyond.html |title=The Warrant Canary in 2010 and Beyond |first=John |last=Kozubik |date=August 6, 2010 |publisher=Blog.kozubik.com |accessdate=2013-06-13}}</ref>
On November 5, 2013, Apple became the most prominent company to publicly state that it had never received an order for user data under Section 215 of the Patriot Act.<ref name=ars1>{{cite web|last=Farivar|first=Cyrus|title=Apple takes strong privacy stance in new report, publishes rare "warrant canary"|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/11/apple-takes-strong-privacy-stance-in-new-report-publishes-rare-warrant-canary/|publisher=ArsTechnica.com|accessdate=5 November 2013|date=5 November 2013<!-- Please don't use for "not tested in any court" claim - circular. See Talk-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://images.apple.com/pr/pdf/131105reportongovinforequests3.pdf |title=Report on Government Access Requests |publisher=Apple.com |date=November 5, 2013 |accessdate=2013-11-15}}</ref> On September 18, 2014, GigaOm reported that the warrant canary statement did not appear anymore in the next two Apple Transparency Reports, covering July–December 2013 and January–June 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://gigaom.com/2014/09/18/apples-warrant-canary-disappears-suggesting-new-patriot-act-demands/|title = Apple's "warrant canary" disappears, suggesting new Patriot Act demands|date = 2014-09-18|accessdate = 2014-09-18|website = Gigaom|publisher = |last = Roberts|first = Jeff John}}</ref> [[Tumblr]] also included a warrant canary in the transparency report that it issued on February 3, 2014.<ref name="Tumblr Daily Dot">{{cite news|last=Collier|first=Kevin|title=The NSA could not care less about your Tumblr blog|url=http://www.dailydot.com/news/tumblr-nsa-transparency-report/|publisher=[[The Daily Dot]]|accessdate=13 February 2014|date=4 February 2014}}</ref> In August 2014, the online cloud service [[Spider Oak]] implemented an encrypted warrant canary that publishes an "All Clear!" message every 6 months. Three PGP signatures from geographically distributed signers must sign each message — so if a government agency forced SpiderOak to update the page, they would need to enlist the help of all three signers.<ref name="Kumparak-2014">{{cite web|last1=Kumparak|first1=Greg|title=SpiderOak Implements A Warrant Canary|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/08/14/spideroak-implements-a-warrant-canary/|website=TechCrunch|publisher=AOL Inc.|accessdate=28 January 2017|date=14 August 2014}}</ref>
In September 2014, US security researcher [[Moxie Marlinspike]] wrote that "every lawyer I've spoken to has indicated that having a 'canary' you remove or choose not to update would likely have the same legal consequences as simply posting something that explicitly says you've received something."<ref name="Marlinspike-2014">{{cite web|url=https://github.com/WhisperSystems/whispersystems.org/issues/34#issuecomment-56448994 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027143819/https://github.com/WhisperSystems/whispersystems.org/issues/34 |archivedate=27 October 2014 |title=If it's illegal to advertise that you've received a court order of some kind... |last=Marlinspike |first=Moxie |website=GitHub |date=22 September 2014 |accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Meyer|first1=David|title=How Reddit Strongly Hinted It Received a Secret Surveillance Order|url=http://fortune.com/2016/04/01/reddit-warrant-canary/|website=Fortune|publisher=Time Inc.|accessdate=3 April 2016|date=1 April 2016}}</ref>
[[Australia]] outlawed the use of a certain kind of warrant canary in March 2015, making it illegal for a journalist to "disclose information about the existence or non-existence" of a warrant issued under new mandatory data retention laws.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://boingboing.net/2015/03/26/australia-outlaws-warrant-cana.html | title=Australia outlaws warrant canaries | work=Boing Boing | accessdate=March 26, 2015 | author=Doctorow, Cory}}</ref> It is unlikely a journalist could give a correct canary in this situation anyway, as under this legislation the agency obtaining the warrant is not compelled to inform the journalist of the warrant.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/mar/19/australias-new-improved-data-retention-laws-how-will-they-work | title=Australia's new 'improved' data retention laws: how will they work? | work=Guardian Australia | accessdate=March 30, 2015 | author=Hurst, Daniel}}</ref> Afterwards, computer security and privacy specialist [[Bruce Schneier]] wrote in a blog post that "[p]ersonally, I have never believed [warrant canaries] would work. It relies on the fact that a prohibition against speaking doesn't prevent someone from not speaking. But courts generally aren't impressed by this sort of thing, and I can easily imagine a secret warrant that includes a prohibition against triggering the warrant canary. And for all I know, there are right now secret legal proceedings on this very issue."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2015/03/australia_outla.html |title=Australia Outlaws Warrant Canaries |author= Schneier, Bruce |authorlink=Bruce Schneier |website=Schneier on Security |date=31 March 2015 |accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref>
That said, case law specific to the [[United States]] would render the covert continuance of warrant canaries subject to constitutionality challenges. [[West Virginia State Board of Education v. Barnette]] and [[Wooley v. Maynard]] rule the Free Speech Clause prohibits compelling someone to speak against one's wishes; this can easily be extended to prevent someone from being compelled to lie. [[New York Times Co. v. United States]] protects one exercising the First Amendment to publish government information, even if it is against the wishes of the government, except under grave and exceptional circumstances previously set by act and precedent. The latter also carries the weight of acting against a direct government intervention similar to a government intervention against a warrant canary.

==Canary Watch==
In 2015, a coalition of organizations consisting of the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]], [[Freedom of the Press Foundation]], [[New York University School of Law|NYU Law]], the [[Calyx Institute]], and the [[Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society|Berkman Center]] created a website called Canary Watch in order to provide a compiled list of all companies providing warrant canaries. Its mission was to provide prompt updates of any changes in a canary's state. It is often difficult for users to ascertain a canary's validity on their own and thus Canary Watch aimed to provide a simple display of all active canaries and any blocks of time that they were not active.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://rt.com/usa/230055-canary-website-information-requests/ | title=Canary Watch: Activists create website to track & reveal NSA, FBI info requests | work=Russian Times | date=6 February 2015 | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.gizmag.com/canary-watch-government-information-requests/35932/ | title=Canary Watch tracks government requests for your information online | work=Gizmag | date=4 February 2015 | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> In May 2016, it was announced that Canary Watch "will no longer accept submissions of new canaries or monitor the existing canaries for changes or take downs".<ref name="Quintin-2016-05-25">{{Cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2016/05/canary-watch-one-year-later|title=Canary Watch – One Year Later|last=Quintin|first=Cooper|website=Deeplinks|type=Blog|publisher=Electronic Frontier Foundation|date=25 May 2016|accessdate=15 July 2016}}</ref> The coalition of organizations which created Canary Watch explained their decision to discontinue the project by stating that it has achieved its goals to raise awareness about "illegal and unconstitutional national security process, including National Security Letters and other secret court processes." The Electronic Frontier Foundation also noted that "the fact that canaries are non-standard makes it difficult to automatically monitor them for changes or takedowns".<ref name="Quintin-2016-05-25"/>

{{Infobox scientist | name=Willgodt Theophil Odhner | image= Odhner.jpg | caption= | birth_date=10 August 1845 | birth_place=[[Dalby, Värmland|Dalby]], [[Värmland]], Sweden | residence= | nationality=Swede/Russian | death_date={{d-da|15 September 1905|10 August 1845}} | death_place=Saint Petersburg, Russia | field= | work_institution= | alma_mater= | doctoral_advisor= | doctoral_students= | known_for=[[Odhner Arithmometer]] | prizes= | religion= | footnotes= }}
'''Willgodt Theophil Odhner''' (in [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]], Вильгодт Теофил Однер) was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] engineer and entrepreneur, working in [[St. Petersburg]], [[Russia]]. He was the inventor of the [[Odhner Arithmometer]], which by the 1940s was one of the most popular type of portable [[Calculator#The_19th_century|mechanical calculator]] in the world.<ref name="Trogemann">Trogemann G., Nitussov A.: ''Computing in Russia'', page 39-45, GWV-Vieweg, 2001, {{ISBN|3-528-05757-2}}</ref>
According to a brochure distributed by Odhner's company at the Paris World exposition of 1900 "...Odhner had, in 1871, an opportunity to repair a [[Arithmometer|Thomas calculating machine]] and then became convinced that it is possible to solve the problem of mechanical calculation by a simpler and more appropriate way". It took him 19 years to perfect the design of this new machine so it could be manufactured effectively.
==Early years== Odhner studied at the [[Royal Institute of Technology]] in [[Stockholm]] from 1864 to 1867 but left before graduating.<ref name="Trogemann"/> At age 23, in 1868, he moved to [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]], even though he didn't speak any Russian. As soon as he arrived, he went to the Swedish consulate, which found him a job in a local mechanical workshop. A few months later he joined the Nobel's mechanical factory owned by a Swede named Ludvig Nobel (1831–1888), brother of [[Alfred Nobel]] of Nobel Prize fame, where he worked until 1877. In 1878 he joined the Expedition, a large paper mill and printing house, and worked there until 1892.
==Manufacturing of the Arithmometer== While working at the Expedition, Odhner started his own workshop in 1885,<ref name="Trogemann"/> building high quality production machines for local manufacturing businesses. One of his biggest project was the manufacturing of printing presses, he also made cigarette-making machines and all kind of scientific instruments. Odhner officially started the production of his arithmometer in this workshop in 1890. Early on, Mr. F. N. Hill, a British citizen, became his associate but he left the company around 1897, making Odhner the sole proprietor until his death in 1905.
After Odhner's death, his sons Alexander and Georg and son-in-law Karl Siewert continued the production and about 23,000 calculators were made before the factory was forced to close down in 1918.
Independent [[Clone (computing)|clone]] makers from all over the world, including Russia, carried the design from 1893 well into the 1970s. [[File:Odhner made before 1900.jpg|thumb|center|400px|An early machine built by W.T. Odhner in St. Petersburg before 1900]]
==Family== In 1871 he married Alma Skånberg the daughter of Fredrik Skånberg, a Nobel coworker. They had seven children. Unfortunately Emilia, their second child, died at age 2 in 1877, the same year Alma, their third child was born.
W. T. Odhner died of a heart attack on 15 September 1905 ([[Gregorian calendar]]) in Saint Petersburg, Russia.

[[Image:YangshupuWaterworks4.jpg|thumb|The main entrance to the waterworks.]] The '''Yangshupu Waterworks''' (Chinese: 杨树浦水厂) is a waterworks built in 1883, and located at 830 Yangshupu Road (杨树浦路830号) in the district of [[Yangpu District|Yangpu]], [[Shanghai]], [[China]]. The waterworks was the first of its kind to be built in China and provided running water for the first time to some of the cities' residents. It belongs to the Shanghai Water Company and occupies a site of 12.9 hectares and has four major lines of tap water allowing for a maximum capacity of around 1.5 million cubic metres a day. In 2009 it supplied 400 million cubic metres of water, about 20% of the total water supply of Shanghai.
In 2013, the site was designated as a [[Major Historical and Cultural Site Protected at the National Level]] by the [[State Council of the People's Republic of China|State Council]] of China, one of [[List of Major National Historical and Cultural Sites in Shanghai|28 sites in Shanghai]]. The site is also of importance due to the effect it had on China's early modern industries in the 1880s and 1890s, with many factories being built around the waterworks providing electricity, gas, vehicles and textiles. It is regarded as the birthplace of China's modern industry by the Shanghai municipal government. Furthermore, the site is protected due to its unique architecture.
To the east and west of the waterworks used to lie the docks. The waterworks lie to the south west of the [[Yangshupu Power Plant|Yangshupu Power Station]].
==History== [[File:杨树浦水厂图纸.jpg|thumb|A drawing of the planned pumping station from 1880 or 1881.]] [[File:Yangshupu Water Plant.jpg|thumb|The waterworks during the late Qing dynasty period of either the 1890s or 1910s.]] In 1880 the Shanghai Waterworks Co. Ltd were founded in London, United Kingdom. British and Chinese engineers provided expertise with British investors providing the funds, to built a waterworks in Shanghai in what was at that time the [[Shanghai International Settlement]], a merging of the previous British and American settlement areas which had existed before 1863. Building started in August 1881 and the design was carried out by the British architect J.W. Hart (赫德), in the style of an English castle.
On 29 June 1883, [[Li Hongzhang]] the [[Viceroy of Zhili]] of the Qing Dynasty, opened the water gate valve and thus opened the waterworks. It was the first waterworks to be built in China, and at the time of its construction the largest in East Asia. During the 1930s the site was much larger spanning 25.9 hectares.<ref>[https://www.shine.cn/archive/District/yangpu/Knowledge-the-key-for-Yangpu/shdaily.shtml Shanghai Daily - Knowledge The Key For Yangpu]. 31 August 2009.</ref>
In 1911, Zhabei Waterworks (闸北水厂) was built to the west of Yangshupu Waterworks on Hengfeng Road. It supplied water to residents and factories on that side of the city, decreasing the usage of the Yangshupu Waterworks. In 1926 the waterworks in Zhabei were moved to their present location on Zhayin Road.<ref>[http://english.eastday.com/eastday/englishedition/Districts/Yangpu/userobject1ai1322944.html Shanghai Daily - Old Buildings Worth A Look]. 8 August 2005.</ref>
By the 1950s, the waterworks was providing around 300,000 cubic metres of water a day.<ref>[http://www.china.org.cn/living_in_china/news/2009-07/30/content_18236242.htm Shanghai Daily - Preserving Historic Factories]. 30 July 2009.</ref>
On 10 March 2001, for the first time in its history the waterworks opened its gates to the general public. Several thousand Shanghai residents applied for tickets.<ref>[http://www.china.org.cn/english/TR-e/9415.htm People's Daily - Visiting Factories: New Modes of Tourism in Shanghai]. 21 March 2001.</ref>
<gallery mode=packed heights=140> File:Shanghai. Water works Yangtzefoo Road (NYPL Hades-2359414-4043770).jpg File:Tcitp d401 shanghai waterworks co.jpg File:Tcitp d402 shanghai waterworks.jpg </gallery>
==Architecture== The buildings and its perimeter wall were designed to resemble English castles featuring pink and grey brickwork and mock turrets. At the top of the walls and on the roofs are crenellation to resemble a castle's parapet. <gallery mode=packed heights=140> File:YangshupuWaterworks.JPG File:YangshupuWaterworks2.jpg File:YangshupuWaterworks3.jpg </gallery>
==Protection== [[Image:YangshupuWaterworks1.jpg|thumb|State protection plaque.]] In 1989, the site was designated a monument of importance for the city of Shanghai, and became protected and preserved as a historical site by the Shanghai city government.
In 2013, the site was designated (7-1694) a Major Historical and Cultural Site Protected at the National Level by the State Council of China, giving it national protection.
==Shanghai Waterworks Science and Technology Museum== Some of the buildings of the site now host the Shanghai Waterworks Science and Technology Museum (上海自来水科技馆) which was opened in Autumn 2003. It has three exhibitions detailing the history, technology and future of the waterworks.
==Surroundings== [[File:杨树浦水厂.jpg|thumb|The waterworks is situated on the north bank of the river.]] Due to the importance of its role in supplying running water, numerous factories and workshops were rapidly built around the Yangshupu Road, many of which were likewise the first of their kind in China.<ref>[http://yptimes.cn/resfile/2017-10-28/07/07.pdf 杨浦时报 - New Casual Dining Project Added to Oriental Fisherman's Wharf]. 28 October 2017</ref> The most important are listed below:
* Yangshupu Shipyard (杨树浦船坞), built in 1862 and modernised in the 1880s. * Shanghai Papermaking Factory (上海天章记录纸厂), built in 1882. * Yangshupu Waterworks Workshop (杨树浦水厂车间), built in 1883. * Shanghai No. 3 Silk Mill (上海第三丝织厂), built in 1888. * Shanghai No. 5 Textile Mill (上海第五毛纺织厂), built in 1896. * Shanghai No. 1 Silk Mill (上海第一丝织厂), built in 1898. * Shanghai Power Station Auxiliary Engine Factory (上海电站辅机厂), built in 1912. * [[Yangshupu Power Plant|Yangshupu Power Station]] (杨树浦发电厂), built in 1913. * Shanghai No. 1 Wool Mill (上海第一毛条厂), built in 1915. * Shanghai Soap Factory (上海制皂厂), built in 1923. * Shanghai Tram Workshop (上海电车厂), built in 1925. * Shanghai Naval Machinery Factory (上海中华造船厂工人加工舰艇部件), built in 1926. * Yangshupu Gasworks (杨树浦煤气厂), built in 1933. * Shanghai Fish Market (上海鱼市场), built in 1935.
Opposite the waterworks are the sites of:
* Shanghai Water Supply Trade Association (上海市供水行业协会) * Shanghai Institute of Water Education (上海水务进修学校)
To the south of the waterworks, facing the [[Huangpu River]] where once the docks stood, is the Yangpu Riverside (杨浦滨江) park and promenade opened in 2017.

Xing Jianrong. April 2004. * [http://en.cnki.com.cn/Article_en/CJFDTOTAL-ZSJS200305005.htm The First Constructed Water Plant: Yangshupu Water Plant]. Gu Zhengguo. May 2005.

{{infobox company |name = Zi Corporation |former_name = Multi-Corp Inc |logo = Zi Corporation.jpg |logo_size = 110px |type = [[Privately held company|Private]] |traded_as = {{ublist|{{NASDAQ was|ZICA}}|{{TSX was|ZIC}}}} |industry = [[Software]] |founded = {{start date|1987}} in [[Calgary]], Canada<ref>{{cite web|title=Company Overview of Zi Corporation|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=235233|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref> |fate = Aqcuired by [[Nuance Communications]] |defunct = {{end date|2009|04|09}} |key_people = {{ublist|Milos Djokovic (President and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]])|Blair Mullin ([[Chief financial officer|CFO]]|George Tai ([[Chairman]])}} |areas_served = {{ublist|Canada|China|Sweden|United States}} |products = {{ublist|Decuma|eZiText|eZiType|Qix}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Zi - Corporation review|url=http://www.techvibes.com/company-directory/zi-corporation|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref> |revenue = {{CAD|13323492}} |revenue_year = 2008 |assets = {{CAD|8327550}} |assets_year = 2008 |num_employees = 77 |num_employees_year = 1987 |homepage = <u>zicorp.com</u> (defunct)<!--{{URL|zicorp.com}} now defunct, with link to possible phising site--> |hq_location_city = [[Calgary]] |hq_location_country = Canada }} '''Zi Corporation''' was a [[software]] company based in [[Calgary]], Canada. The company was founded on 4 December 1987 as Cancom Ventures Inc, owning an [[Edmonton]] secretarial college and an industrial equipment rental business. On 30 August 1989 the name was changed to Multi-Corp Inc. In 1993, board member Michael Lobsinger took control of the company, became CEO, and turned the company towards the [[telecommunications]] industry, purchasing several privately held companies involved in the telecommunications businesses,<ref name=China>{{cite web|url=http://www.canadianbusiness.com/business-strategy/china-calling/|title=China calling|publisher=[[Canadian Business]]|date=22 November 2004|last1=Wahl|first1=Andrew|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref> and in November 1993, Multi-Corp entered into an exclusive licensing agreement with Eric Chappell for a stroke-based [[Chinese language|Chinese]] text entry system which they referred to as the ''Jiejing Licenses''.<ref name=Geist>{{cite book|last1=Geist|first1=Richard|title=Investor Therapy: A Psychologist and Investing Guru Tells You How to Out-Psych Wall Street|date=23 Sep 2003|publisher=Crown Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-60960-916-3}}</ref> A wholly owned subsidiary, Ziran Developments Inc, was formed to handle the Chinese text entry business. The company was listed on the [[Toronto Stock Exchange]] on 9 June 1995 (symbol MCU).<ref name=Klein /> Under Lobsinger, the strategic importance of the Chinese text entry grew, and Ziran was renamed Zi Corporation in 1996; ''Zi'' meaning ''character'' in Chinese. The telecommunications businesses were disposed of by 1997<ref>[http://yahoo.brand.edgar-online.com/DisplayFiling.aspx?TabIndex=2&FilingID=5832654&companyid=97501&ppu=%252fdefault.aspx%253fcompanyid%253d97501%2526amp%253bformtypeId%253d53 Zi Corp entry], Edgar Online.</ref> In June 1997, the parent company was renamed Zi Corporation to reflect the importance of the new business. In 1999, co-founder [[Gary Kovacs]] joined as COO.<!-- left in 2003 for Macromedia -->
Having started with Chinese on [[personal computer]]s, toward the end of the 1990s Zi's focus moved to text entry for all languages for [[mobile phone]]s and other handheld devices, where efficient entry of text traditionally has been challenging due to limitations of a physically small device.<ref name=China /> This new business area was quickly quite successful, especially in the Chinese market, and in 1998 Zi entered into licensing agreements with Ericsson (later [[Sony Ericsson]]), who at that time was a very significant player in the Chinese market.<ref name=China /><ref name="1998 Annual Report">{{cite web|title=Zi Corporation 1998 Annual Report|url=http://globaldocuments.morningstar.com/documentlibrary/document/3405d5ef283dbaf1.msdoc/original|website=[[Morningstar, Inc.|Morningstar]]|publisher=Zi Corporation|accessdate=27 December 2015|format=PDF}}</ref> Further license agreements with Ericsson and other companies were to follow, for a total of more than 1000 different device models being shipped with Zi text entry software,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Au|first1=Maggie|title=Sony Ericsson signs expansion deal with Zi Corp.|journal=[[Telecom Asia]]|date=16 September 2008|url=http://www.telecomasia.net/content/sony-ericsson-signs-expansion-deal-zi-corp-0|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref> in more than 100 million devices.<ref name=VisionMobile>{{cite web|last1=Constantinou|first1=Andreas|title=Watchlist: The 100 million club|url=http://www.visionmobile.com/blog/2008/04/watchlist-the-100-million-club/|publisher=[[VisionMobile]]|date=2008|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
The introduction of [[touch screen]] technology for mobile devices made the company follow up with software for handwriting recognition, with focus on languages such as Chinese and [[Japanese language|Japanese]]. In 2003, Mike Donnell took over as CEO from Lobsinger.<ref name=China /> Zi Corporation was listed on [[NASDAQ]] from September 2007 .<ref>[http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/zi-corporation-application-to-trade-on-the-nasdaq-capital-market-approved-nasdaq-zica-766930.htm Zi Corporation Application to Trade on the NASDAQ Capital Market Approved]</ref>
Text entry on devices with limited number of keys was early subject to a number of [[software patent]]s, and Zi was engaged in several costly patent disputes with [[Tegic Corporation]], later [[Nuance Communications]]. In August 2008, Nuance made a takeover bid to acquire the company for {{USD|40.4}} million, which the company declined. Shortly thereafter, Nuance filed a patent infringement lawsuit against Zi.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kapko|first1=Matt|title=Nuance Sues Zi Corp. For Patent Infringement Days After It Rejects Takeover Offer|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/25/AR2008082502093.html|accessdate=27 December 2015|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|date=25 August 2008}}</ref><ref name=xconomy>{{cite web|url=http://www.xconomy.com/boston/2008/08/18/canadas-zi-corporation-hopes-to-fend-off-nuance-takeover-companies-issue-dueling-statements/ |title=Canada’s Zi Corporation Hopes to Fend Off Nuance Takeover; Companies Issue Dueling Statements|publisher=[[Xconomy]]|accessdate=25 Dec 2015}}</ref> The company was finally acquired by Nuance for {{USD|35}} million on 26 February 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/mass-high-tech/2009/02/nuance-buys-zi-corp-for-35m.html|title=Nuance buys Zi Corp. for $35M|publisher=[[Boston Business Journal]]|date=27 February 2009|accessdate=25 Dec 2015}}</ref> and the acquisition was completed on 9 April 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nuance.com/news/pressreleases/2009/20090409_ziClosing.asp |title=Nuance Closes Acquisition of Zi Corporation|publisher=Nuance Communications|date=27 February 2009|accessdate=29 Dec 2015}}</ref>
==Products== Zi's main product was ''EZiText'' [[predictive text entry]] software, in competition with solutions such as the original [[T9 (predictive text)|T9]] product from Tegic, later Nuance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2006/06/16/zi-announces-advanced-chinese-text-messaging-input-system/ |title=Zi announces advanced Chinese text messaging input system]|publisher=[[Engadget]]|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref> Other products include ''eZiType'', a predictive text entry product for mobile email users, for keyboard-based mobile devices, ''Qix'', a service discovery engine that provides a quick and easy method for accessing a phone's features, applications, and services, and ''Decuma'' which delivers an input method for pen-based devices by fusing handwriting recognition with predictive text technology.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zi Corporation Completes Acquisition of Assets of Decuma AB of Sweden|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20050126005704/en/Zi-Corporation-Completes-Acquisition-Assets-Decuma-AB|accessdate=29 December 2015|date=26 January 2005}}</ref>
==Patent war== There was a series of [[patent infringement]] lawsuits between Tegic, the holder of the T9 patents, and Zi: * A patent infringement lawsuit by Zi against Tegic, filed in the District Court in Seattle for Japanese and Chinese character-based text input technologies was dismissed in September 1999.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tegic Wins Patent Infringement Dispute; U.S. District Court In Seattle Summarily Dismisses Zi Corp Claims.|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Tegic+Wins+Patent+Infringement+Dispute%3B+U.S.+District+Court+In...-a055731624|accessdate=29 December 2015|date=13 September 1999}}</ref> * In February 2002, the District Court for Northern California granted Zi a partial summary judgment that eZiText for alphabetic does not infringe on Tegic's patents.<ref>{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}</ref> * In March 2002, the Federal District Court for the Western District of Washington granted Zi partial summary judgment stating that eZiText for alphabetic languages does not infringe Tegic's text input patents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Zi+Claims+Second+Patent+Victory+Against+Tegic+Communications,+a+Unit...-a083757620|title=Zi Claims Second Patent Victory Against Tegic Communications, a Unit of AOL Time Warner.|date=14 March 2002|accessdate=29 December 2015}}</ref> * In September 2002, the U.S. District Court for Northern California awarded Tegic, owned by [[AOL]] [[Time Warner]], {{USD|9}} million in damages for Zi's infringement of two Tegic patents. Zi's claim that the two Tegic patents were based on existing methods of inputting Chinese ideographic characters were rejected.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tegic Hails Sweeping Legal Victory in Patent Infringement Lawsuit Against Zi Corporation|url=http://www.timewarner.com/newsroom/press-releases/2002/09/05/tegic-hails-sweeping-legal-victory-in-patent-infringement-lawsuit|accessdate=29 December 2015|publisher=[[Time Warner]]|date=5 September 2002}}</ref> * In August 2008 Nuance filed a patent infringement lawsuit against Zi in the Federal Court in Toronto, Canada, where Nuance accuses Zi of infringing Canadian Patent Numbers 2,399,961 and 2,278,549, each entitled "Reduced Keyboard Disambiguating System.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nuance and Its Subsidiary Tegic Communications File Patent Infringement Lawsuit Against Zi Corporation|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUS143090+25-Aug-2008+BW20080825|accessdate=29 December 2015|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=25 August 2008}}</ref>
== Other controversies == * In 1995 the company sold stock to the wives of [[Alberta]] Premier [[Ralph Klein]] and his chief of staff [[Rod Love]] well below market value, with no payment required until they sold them. Klein had participated in a ribbon-cutting ceremony at the company’s Hong Kong office while Love served as a company director. Klein was later cleared of wrongdoing in a decision by Alberta's Ethics Commissioner [[Robert Curtis Clark|Bob Clark]],<ref name=China /><ref name=Klein>{{cite web|title=Investigation Report: November 10, 1995 1 REPORT OF INVESTIGATION INTO ALLEGATIONS RELATING TO THE HON. RALPH KLEIN, PREMIER|url=http://www.ethicscommissioner.ab.ca/media/1057/multicorp95.pdf|publisher=Alberta Ethics Commissioner|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref name=Post>{{cite web|url=http://www.canadianhedgewatch.com/content/news/general/?id=205 |title=Calgary firm linked to hedge fund investigation|website=Canadian Hedgewatch|publisher=[[National Post]]|date=12 August 2003|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref> although this decision was controversial.<ref name=Teflon>{{cite web|url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/news/alberta/ralph+klein+teflon+premier+nine+lives/8171734/story.html||last1=Henton|first1=Darcy|title=Ralph Klein—the Teflon premier—and his nine lives|publisher=[[Calgary Herald]]|date=28 March 2013|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref name=Western>{{cite news|last1=Mrozek|first1=Andrea|title=The Right Connections|url=http://investorvoice.ca/PI/2439.htm|accessdate=27 December 2015|publisher=[[Western Standard]]|date=12 December 2005}}</ref> * In 1998, Eric Chappell receives 4.5 million shares as compensation for transfer of all rights of the ''Jiejing Licenses'' to Zi. 3 million shares, representing 11.5% of the shares, are sold to Lancer Funds without disclosure, as is required by law.<ref name=Western /> * In 2003, the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] froze the assets of Lancer Group, a [[hedge fund]] investment management firm, when it discovered it owned 49.1% of Zi's shares, far beyond the 10% limit requiring disclosure. This was suspected to be for market manipulation, and the Lancer assets were taken over by an appointed receiver.<ref name=China /><ref name=Post /> Zi entered into a settlement agreement with the SEC.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zi Corporation and Marty Steinberg, Receiver for the Lancer Funds, Enter into Settlement Agreement|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/922658/000120445907000264/zic0223exh991.htm|publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref>
